content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Emily Martinez: Well, I was born in Portland, Oregon, and I've lived here most of my life. I grew up in a small house on Pinecrest Avenue with my parents and my two younger siblings. My dad worked at a local factory, and my mom stayed home for a while, but she eventually started doing some part-time work at a community center. We weren't rich, but we had everything we needed. My parents both only went through high school, so they always encouraged me and my siblings to do better. I was a pretty quiet kid, always more interested in books and art than sports or parties. I remember spending a lot of time in the library, and I loved drawing. I got into a good high school, and I worked hard to keep my grades up. I didn't have a lot of money, so I had to work part-time at a café during high school to help out. It was tough balancing school and work, but I managed. I'm still in school now, trying to figure out what I want to do with my life. I've always been interested in design, so maybe I'll go into something like graphic design or architecture. I'm not sure yet, but I know I want to make something of myself.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Emily Martinez: There was a moment in my sophomore year of high school that really shaped the direction of my life. I had been working at the café after school, and I was struggling to keep up with the workload. One day, I was really stressed and overwhelmed, and I ended up skipping art class to take a break. My art teacher, Mrs. Delgado, noticed I wasn't there and came looking for me. She found me in the library, and instead of scolding me, she sat down and talked to me. She asked me what I was interested in, and I told her I loved drawing and designing things. She encouraged me to join the school's design club, even though I was hesitant at first. That club became a turning point for me. I started getting involved in design projects, and I realized that I had a real passion for it. It also helped me focus more in school because I had something I was genuinely excited about. That experience made me realize that I needed to take my education seriously and explore my interests more deeply. It was the first time I felt like I had a real direction, and it pushed me to work harder and think about my future in a more intentional way.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Emily Martinez: I think it was a mix of both, honestly. I wasn't sure what I wanted to do with my life, but that conversation with Mrs. Delgado made me realize that I had a choice. I didn't just fall into design—it was something I had to choose to pursue. I remember thinking, 'Why didn't I try this sooner?' But at the same time, I think I was ready for it. I had been working so hard in school and at the café, and I was tired of feeling like I was just going through the motions. That moment with her was the push I needed to make a conscious decision to follow my passion, even if I didn't know exactly where it would take me. It wasn't just luck or chance—it was a choice I made because I finally saw a path that felt like it was meant for me.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Emily Martinez: Absolutely, I think someone like Mrs. Delgado was exactly the kind of person who could have made a difference. I don't know if I would have found my passion for design on my own if someone hadn't pointed it out to me. I remember feeling so stuck and unsure of myself, and she saw something in me that I didn't even realize I had. I also think organizations like the school's design club played a role in giving me the tools and the confidence to explore that path. If I had been in a different school or if the club hadn't existed, I might not have had the same opportunity. It's not just about individual effort—it's also about having the right support system in place. I'm really grateful for people like her who took the time to care and help others find their way.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Emily Martinez: Right now, I don't have a partner or any children. I'm still focused on my education and figuring out my future. My family is really important to me, though. My parents are both still living in the same house on Pinecrest Avenue, and my two younger siblings are in high school and college now. My mom recently started working full-time at the community center, which has been a big change for our family. She's been really proud of me for staying in school and working hard. My dad still works at the factory, and while it's not the easiest job, he's always been supportive of me and my siblings. We don't have a lot of money, but we're close-knit and we always look out for each other. I think that's one of the reasons I've always felt motivated to do well—because I know my family is counting on me, and I want to make them proud.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the people and moments I didn't always expect to matter. Starting from my childhood in Portland, I see how my family's support, even with their own struggles, gave me a foundation to build on. That moment in sophomore year with Mrs. Delgado was a turning point I didn't foresee, but it showed me the power of guidance and encouragement. I realize now that my journey wasn't just about hard work—it was also about the right people being there at the right time. Even now, as I continue my education and think about my future, I carry the lessons from my family, my teachers, and the opportunities I've had. It's all connected, and I'm grateful for every part of it.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Emily Martinez: My grandparents on my mom's side live a few towns over, and we visit them whenever we can. They're both in their 70s now, and they've been through a lot. My grandpa worked on the railroad for most of his life, and my grandma was a nurse before she retired. They've always been a big part of our family, even though we don't see them as often as I'd like. I remember spending summers with them when I was younger, and they always told me stories about their lives, which really shaped my view of the world. My grandma especially encouraged me to read and learn as much as I could, and I think that's why I've always had a love for books. Even though we don't talk every day, I know they're proud of me, and I try to stay in touch as much as I can. Family means a lot to me, and I'm grateful for all of them, even the ones who live far away.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Emily Martinez: Outside of my family, my closest friends have been the ones who stuck with me through everything. There's Sarah, who I met in high school through the design club. We've been best friends ever since, and she's the one who always pushes me to keep going, even when I feel stuck. She's studying graphic design at a community college now, and I look up to her a lot. Then there's Jake, who works at the café where I used to wait tables. He's been like a brother to me—he's always been there to listen when I needed someone to talk to. I think having friends like them has been just as important as my family. They remind me that I'm not alone in this, and that I have people who believe in me, even when I don't believe in myself. I don't know where I'd be without them.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Emily Martinez: I live in a pretty tight-knit neighborhood in Portland, just a few blocks from where I grew up. It's a mix of old houses and newer apartments, and there are a lot of families like mine—working-class, trying to make the most of what we have. There's a community garden near the corner of Pinecrest and 5th, and I often see people from the neighborhood hanging out there, chatting or tending to their plants. It's a nice reminder that even though life can be tough, there's a real sense of community here. I also like that there are a few local businesses that have been around for years, like the café where I used to work and the little bookstore on the corner. I feel like I know most of the people who live here, and even though I'm still figuring out my future, I'm proud to be part of this place. It's not perfect, but it's home, and I think that matters more than anything.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Emily Martinez: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. It's not like the neighborhoods you hear about in the news—there's no real sense of danger around here. Most people know each other, and there's a kind of unspoken understanding that we all have our struggles, but we also look out for one another. I've never had any real issues with crime or anything like that. The only thing that sometimes worries me is the noise from the highway nearby, but that's more of an annoyance than a safety concern. I think the sense of community here plays a big role in keeping things peaceful. When you know your neighbors and they know you, it makes a difference. I feel like I can walk around here at night without too much worry, and that's something I'm really grateful for.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Emily Martinez: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The good thing is, there's a real sense of community that makes it feel like home. I love knowing the neighbors, and I feel like I can rely on people here when I need help. But it's not without its challenges. Sometimes, the cost of living here can be tough, especially with school and trying to save up for the future. I've had to be really careful with my money, and there are days when I feel like I'm stretching every dollar too thin. Still, I think the positives outweigh the negatives. I've grown up here, and even though I don't know exactly where I'm headed, I know this place has shaped me in ways I can't ignore. It's not just where I live—it's where I started, and that means a lot to me.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me realize how much my roots and the people around me have shaped who I am today. Talking about my parents, siblings, and the support they've given me reminded me of how important family is, even when life is tough. It also made me think about how lucky I am to have friends like Sarah and Jake, who have been there for me through thick and thin. When I described my neighborhood, I felt a sense of pride in the community I've grown up in—it's not perfect, but it's home, and that matters more than anything. I also felt grateful for the safety and sense of belonging I have here, which I think is something a lot of people take for granted. It's amazing how much just talking about these things brought everything into focus for me. I never really stopped to think about how much my family, friends, and neighborhood have influenced my journey, but now I see it clearly. I'm thankful for all of it.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Emily Martinez: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, but there are definitely some variations depending on my classes and how busy I am with school projects. Most days start early—I usually wake up around 7 a.m., have a quick breakfast, and then head to class. I'm taking a mix of general education courses and some design-related classes, so I have a lot of different subjects to juggle. After school, I try to spend some time working on assignments or sketching out ideas for projects. I also work part-time at the café a couple of afternoons a week, which helps me earn some extra money and keeps me connected to the community. On weekends, I like to relax with friends or spend time with my family. Sometimes I'll go to the community garden or just hang out at the bookstore. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I try to stay focused on what matters most—my education and my goals.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Emily Martinez: I work part-time at a local café called 'The Daily Grind,' which is just a few blocks from my house. I usually work two afternoons a week, from 3 p.m. to 7 p.m., which fits around my school schedule. It's a pretty laid-back job, and I've been there for a couple of years now. The staff is like a second family to me—Jake, who I mentioned earlier, is one of the baristas, and we've been working together for almost three years. The owner, Mr. Thompson, is a kind guy who always gives me a break when I need it for school. I enjoy the rhythm of the job—it's not too stressful, and it gives me a chance to interact with people from all over the neighborhood. Plus, it's a good way to earn some money while I figure out what I want to do next. I think working there has also helped me stay grounded, reminding me of where I came from and how important it is to keep pushing forward, even when things get tough.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Emily Martinez: Outside of school and work, I also try to stay active by going for walks or bike rides around the neighborhood. I've always loved being outdoors, and it helps me clear my mind when I'm feeling overwhelmed with everything going on. I also make it a point to volunteer at the community center a few times a month, especially on weekends when I have more free time. It's a way for me to give back, and I feel like it connects me to the people and causes that matter to me. My mom used to volunteer there too, so it feels like a family tradition in a way. I also have a small routine of reading every night before bed—it's something I picked up from my grandma, and it's become a comfort to me. Even though life can be stressful, these little habits help me stay grounded and focused on what's important.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Emily Martinez: One of the biggest changes to my daily routine has been starting to take online courses in graphic design through a local community college. I've been working on them in the evenings after my shifts at the café, which has been a bit of a challenge, but it's also been really rewarding. I used to just sketch ideas in my notebook, but now I'm actually learning the software and tools that professionals use. It's opened up a whole new world for me, and I feel like I'm finally taking real steps toward the future I want. I've also started setting aside specific times each day for planning and goal-setting, which has helped me stay on track with my studies and work. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I'm learning to manage my time better, and I think it's making a real difference in how I approach my day.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Emily Martinez: I don't have children yet, but I can tell you about my younger siblings—they're the ones who keep me grounded and remind me of what it's like to be a teenager. My younger brother, Alex, is in his senior year of high school, and he's been really focused on getting into a good college. He's into photography, just like I used to be with drawing, and he's been working on a portfolio to apply for art programs. My sister, Maria, is in her first year of college, studying social work. She's always been the more outgoing one, and she's really passionate about helping others. After school, Alex usually spends time at the community center working on his projects or hanging out with friends, while Maria is either in class or volunteering at a local shelter. They both have their own paths, and it's amazing to see them grow and find their way. I think having siblings like them has been a big part of my life too—they've always pushed me to be better and reminded me that there's more to life than just school and work.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and daily routines made me realize how deeply connected I am to the people and places that have shaped my life. Talking about my parents, siblings, and the support they've given me reminded me of how important family is, even when life is tough. It also made me think about how lucky I am to have friends like Sarah and Jake, who have been there for me through thick and thin. When I described my neighborhood, I felt a sense of pride in the community I've grown up in—it's not perfect, but it's home, and that matters more than anything. I also felt grateful for the safety and sense of belonging I have here, which I think is something a lot of people take for granted. It's amazing how much just talking about these things brought everything into focus for me. I never really stopped to think about how much my family, friends, and neighborhood have influenced my journey, but now I see it clearly. I'm thankful for all of it.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Emily Martinez: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm pretty average. I don't have any major medical issues, but I do struggle with stress from time to time, especially with balancing school, work, and trying to plan for the future. I've been dealing with some anxiety off and on, especially when I'm overwhelmed with deadlines or worried about money. I try to manage it by staying active, like going for walks or bike rides, and by talking to friends or family when I need to. I also make sure to eat reasonably well, even if I don't always have the best meals—sometimes it's just whatever I can afford. I've been thinking about seeing a counselor at the community center, just to get some professional support, but I haven't made the appointment yet. I know it's something I should do, but I'm still figuring out how to make time for it. Overall, I feel healthy enough to keep going, but I know I could use some help managing the stress better.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Emily Martinez: Staying healthy isn't always easy for me, honestly. It's not just about the physical stuff—it's also about the mental load I carry. Money is always on my mind, and that stress can really take a toll. Sometimes I skip meals because I'm too busy or too worried about paying for groceries, and other times I eat the same thing over and over because it's cheap and easy. I know I should be eating better, but it's hard when you're stretched thin. What makes it easier is knowing that I have people around me who care. My friends, my family—they remind me to take a breath and not forget to take care of myself. I also find that staying active, even if it's just a short walk or a bike ride, helps me feel more grounded. It's not perfect, but I'm learning that taking small steps to take care of myself is just as important as everything else I'm trying to do.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Emily Martinez: In the past two years, I haven't had any major health issues or diagnoses, but I have dealt with some ongoing stress and anxiety, especially as I've been juggling school, work, and trying to plan for the future. There was a time last year when I was really overwhelmed with a big design project and a lot of deadlines, and I started having trouble sleeping. I was constantly worried about money and whether I was on the right path. It got to the point where I felt like I was running on empty, and I had to take a step back and remind myself that I wasn't alone. I started talking more to Sarah and Jake, and that helped a lot. I also began going for walks more often, which made a big difference in how I felt. I think the hardest part is that I don't always prioritize my own well-being when things get tough. I know I should be taking better care of myself, but it's easy to put that on the back burner when you're focused on everything else. Still, I'm learning that taking even small steps—like getting enough sleep, eating something healthy, or just taking a few minutes to breathe—can make a real difference in how I feel day to day.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Emily Martinez: Honestly, I haven't had any health issues that have really stopped me from working or taking care of my family, but I know that if something were to happen, it could definitely make things harder. I've been lucky so far, but I also know that stress and anxiety can take a toll over time. If I ever did face something like that, I think the biggest challenge would be finding the time and resources to take care of myself. I don't have a lot of money, and healthcare can be expensive, so I worry about what would happen if I needed something more serious. But I also know that my family and friends would support me, and I'd try to find ways to make it work. I just hope I never have to face something like that, but I'm trying to be more proactive about my health now—like talking to someone about my anxiety and making sure I take care of myself before things get too overwhelming.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Emily Martinez: Over the past year, I've been going through a lot of personal growth, even if it hasn't always felt like it at the time. I've been trying to balance school, work, and my own goals more carefully, and I think I've gotten a little better at managing my time and stress. I still have my moments of doubt, especially when I'm looking at the bigger picture and wondering if I'm on the right track, but I'm starting to feel more confident in the choices I've made. I've also been trying to take better care of myself—eating a little more regularly, going for walks more often, and even starting to think about seeing a counselor at the community center. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that small changes can make a big difference. I've also been really grateful for the support from my family and friends, especially during tough times. They've reminded me that I'm not alone, and that gives me the strength to keep going. I know there's still a lot to figure out, but I feel like I'm finally starting to see a clearer path ahead.

Going through the interview questions about my recent changes, daily routines, and health made me realize how much I've grown over the past year, even if it hasn't always felt like it. Starting online courses in graphic design was a big step for me—it felt like the first real move toward the future I've been trying to imagine. It wasn't easy balancing it with work and school, but I'm proud of myself for pushing through. At the same time, talking about my health and stress made me face some uncomfortable truths. I've been putting a lot on myself, and I haven't always taken care of my mental and physical well-being the way I should. But I'm starting to see that it's okay to ask for help, whether it's from friends, family, or even a counselor. I've always thought I had to do everything on my own, but now I understand that taking care of myself is just as important as working hard. It's a lesson I hope to carry with me as I move forward.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Emily Martinez: I think I've definitely struggled with anxiety, especially over the past year as I've been trying to juggle so many things at once. There were times when I felt like I was constantly on edge, worrying about money, school, and whether I was making the right choices for my future. I used to push through it by telling myself I just had to keep going, but I realize now that ignoring it doesn't make it go away. I've had moments where I felt like I couldn't breathe, or my mind would race with thoughts I couldn't control. I know that's not something to be ashamed of, but I also know it's something I need to take seriously. I've started talking to Sarah more about it, and she's been really supportive. I think the hardest part is that I don't always know how to ask for help, or I feel like I don't have the time or resources to do something about it. But I'm trying to change that. I've even started looking into low-cost counseling options at the community center, and I hope to make an appointment soon. I know I can't do this alone, and I'm learning that it's okay to reach out when I need to.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Emily Martinez: For my family, it's been a mix of challenges and small victories. My mom's been working full-time now, which has been a big adjustment for us. She's always been a pillar of strength, but I can see how tired she gets some days. My dad still works the same factory job, and while he's never complained, I know it's not easy for him either. But they both keep pushing forward, and that's something I admire so much. My siblings are doing well too—Alex is applying to colleges, and Maria is getting settled into her first year of college. It's been a lot for them, but they're both really determined. I think what's been hardest for my family is the financial strain, but we've always been close, and we support each other through it. Even when things feel overwhelming, we remind ourselves that we're in this together, and that gives us the strength to keep going.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Emily Martinez: For me, religion has always been a part of my life, even if it's not something I talk about a lot. I was raised Protestant, just like my parents and grandparents, and I still go to church with my family on Sundays. It's not about being perfect or following every rule—it's more about the sense of community and the comfort that comes from knowing I'm not alone in this world. My grandma used to say that faith was like a compass, and even when life felt confusing, it helped me stay grounded. I don't always feel like I have all the answers, but I do believe in something bigger than myself. It's not the most important thing in my life, but it's one of those quiet, steady parts that I'm grateful for. I think it's helped me through some tough times, especially when I was feeling lost or unsure of what I wanted to do with my life. I don't know if I'd call myself spiritual in the traditional sense, but I do believe in the power of love, family, and doing the right thing—even when it's hard.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Emily Martinez: I don't use social media a whole lot, honestly. I know a lot of people my age are always on their phones, scrolling through Instagram or Facebook, but I've never really felt the need for it. I guess I'm more of a private person—I don't like sharing every little detail of my life online. I do follow some art and design accounts for inspiration, and I'll sometimes look up local events or job postings, but that's about it. I think I'm more of a people person in real life, so I prefer talking to friends face-to-face or meeting up with them instead of just liking posts or commenting on someone's day. I also worry about how much time people spend on social media these days—it feels like it can be so consuming, and I don't want to get caught up in that. I know I'm missing out on some things, but for now, I'm okay with keeping it simple.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Emily Martinez: Honestly, I don't use social media for support during tough times. I know a lot of people find comfort in sharing their struggles online, but I've always preferred talking to someone in person. When I'm feeling down, I tend to reach out to Sarah or Jake, or I'll go for a walk and just clear my head. I think there's something about being physically present with someone who cares that makes a difference. I've seen how social media can be both a blessing and a burden—sometimes it feels like everyone else has their lives together, and that can make things worse. I don't want to get caught up in that comparison. For me, real support comes from the people I know and trust, not from likes or comments on a post.

Going through the interview questions about my health and recent struggles made me realize how much I've been carrying on my own without really asking for help. It's not that I don't want support—it's more like I've always thought I had to handle everything by myself. But now I see that it's okay to reach out, whether it's to a friend, family member, or even a counselor. I've been dealing with anxiety and stress for a while, and I've ignored it for too long. I know I can't keep pretending everything is fine when it's not. I need to take better care of myself, not just physically but mentally too. I'm starting to understand that taking small steps, like talking to someone or going for a walk, can make a real difference. I'm grateful for the people in my life who have been there for me, and I hope I can be more open about my struggles moving forward. I'm not alone, and I don't have to face everything by myself.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Emily Martinez: Over the past few months, I've noticed that my stress levels have actually gone down a bit, which is a relief. I think it's because I've started setting clearer boundaries for myself—like making time to rest when I need to, even if it's just for a few minutes. I've also been trying to practice mindfulness, something I learned about from a friend who's into meditation. It's not something I do every day, but when I do, it helps me feel more centered. I've also started journaling, which has been a good way to process my thoughts and emotions without getting overwhelmed. I used to think that worrying was just part of life, but now I realize it's something I can manage with the right tools. I'm still learning, and there are definitely days when I feel like I'm back to square one, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and not beat myself up over it. I think the biggest change has been realizing that I don't have to carry everything alone, and that small acts of self-care can make a big difference in how I feel overall.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Emily Martinez: Last month, our biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and my mom's new work-related costs since she started full-time at the community center. Rent is always the largest chunk of our budget—we're lucky to have a modest but stable apartment, and we've been paying the same amount for years. Groceries can be tough because we try to eat healthy but still keep costs down. I've been buying in bulk when I can and using coupons, but it's still a challenge when money is tight. My mom's new job means she has to buy some professional clothes and pay for transportation, which adds up. I also have my tuition and books for the online design courses, which I'm paying for out of my part-time job at the café. It's a lot to juggle, but we've always been good at making do with what we have. I know it's not easy, but we're managing, and I'm trying to make sure I don't add more pressure on my family by not being responsible with my own money.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Emily Martinez: Our household spending last month was pretty close to what we usually spend, though there were a few changes because of my mom's new job. On average, we spend around $2,500 a month. That covers rent, which is about $1,200, groceries around $600, and utilities like electricity and water, which are another $300. My mom's new work-related expenses added about $200 for professional clothes and transportation, and I've been spending around $300 on tuition and books for my online design courses. I also set aside some money for emergencies, even if it's just a small amount. It's not a lot, but it's enough to get by. We've always been careful with our money, and I think that's why we've managed to stay afloat. I know it's not easy, but I'm trying to be responsible with what I earn from the café and with the small savings I've built up over the years. It's a tight budget, but we make it work.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Emily Martinez: We rent our home. It's a small two-bedroom apartment just a few blocks from where I grew up, and it's been our family's home for almost ten years now. Renting has always been the best option for us—buying a house just isn't something we could afford, especially with my parents' education and the way the housing market is. I know it's not ideal, but it works for us. We've been lucky to have a stable landlord who doesn't raise the rent too often, and we've always tried to keep the place in good condition. It's not much, but it's ours, and it's where we've built so many memories. I think one of the things I'm most grateful for is that we've never had to move too far from our neighborhood or our community. It's comforting to know that even though life can be tough, we have a place to come back to, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Emily Martinez: Over the past year, our bills have had their ups and downs, just like everything else. In the winter months, our heating bill went up a bit, which was tough because we're always trying to keep costs low. We had to be extra careful with the thermostat and layer up with blankets to stay warm without turning the heat up too high. Then, when spring came around, the electricity bill went down a little because we were using less heat, but we had to pay for some repairs on the old fridge, which was a surprise expense. Around the holidays, we spent a bit more on groceries and a small gift for my parents, but we kept it simple—nothing too extravagant. School started again in the fall, and that meant more supplies for my siblings, which added to our monthly costs. I also had to pay for my online design courses, which was a new expense for me. Overall, it's been a balancing act, but we've managed to keep things steady by being mindful of what we spend and where we can cut back. I think the biggest thing is that we've learned to plan ahead a little more, like setting aside money for unexpected costs, even if it's just a small amount each month.

Going through the interview questions about my family and my use of social media made me realize how much my family's strength and support have been a constant in my life, even during tough times. It's amazing how much my parents and siblings have endured, yet they always find a way to keep going, and that gives me hope for my own future. At the same time, I've come to appreciate that I don't need social media to feel connected or supported. My real relationships—with friends like Sarah and Jake, and with my family—are what truly matter. I've spent so much time worrying about my own struggles, but now I see that I'm not alone, and that's something I need to hold onto more often.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Emily Martinez: I do have a small savings account, though it's not much. I try to set aside whatever I can from my part-time job at the café, even if it's just a few dollars here and there. It's not always easy when money is tight, but I know that having even a little saved can make a difference in an emergency. I also keep a small jar at home for unexpected expenses, like when the fridge needed repairs last spring. It's not a lot, but it gives me some peace of mind. I know I should be saving more, but I'm learning that even small steps count. I want to be responsible with my money, not just for myself, but also so I don't add more pressure on my family. It's something I'm still working on, but I'm trying to be more mindful of where my money goes and how I can build a better future for myself.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Emily Martinez: In the last year, I've been saving more for a rainy day than for any big purchases, honestly. I know that life can be unpredictable, and I want to be prepared for anything that might come up. I've been trying to set aside a little bit from my paycheck every week, even if it's just $20 or $30. It doesn't seem like much, but over time, it adds up. I also keep a small emergency fund in a jar at home, just in case something unexpected happens, like a car repair or a sudden medical expense. I know I should be saving more for the future, like for when I finish my design courses or if I ever decide to go to college full-time, but right now, I feel like the most important thing is being ready for whatever comes next. I don't want to be caught off guard, and I think having even a little saved gives me a sense of control in a world that can feel so uncertain at times.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Emily Martinez: My occupation right now is a part-time barista at 'The Daily Grind,' which is a small café in my neighborhood. The work is pretty straightforward—making coffee, preparing pastries, and cleaning up after each shift. But what I've come to appreciate most is the way it connects me to the people around me. I get to talk to regulars who come in every day, hear their stories, and sometimes even help them out with something small. The most important part of my job, though, is the rhythm it gives me. It's a way to stay grounded and remind me that even on the hardest days, there's something simple and reliable that I can count on. I also enjoy the creativity that comes with it—like coming up with new drink combinations or decorating the café for holidays. It might not be the most glamorous job, but it's meaningful to me because it helps me support my family and keeps me connected to the community I grew up in.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Emily Martinez: I usually work around 20 hours a week at the café, which fits well with my school schedule. Most weeks, I work two afternoons from 3 p.m. to 7 p.m., and sometimes I'll take an extra shift on the weekends if I need to earn a little more money. It's not always easy balancing work with school and my design courses, but I've gotten pretty good at managing my time. I try to plan my shifts ahead of time so I don't overlap with important assignments or study sessions. The job isn't just about making coffee—it's also about being part of something bigger, like the community here. I've learned a lot from the people I work with, and I think that experience has helped me grow in ways I didn't expect.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Emily Martinez: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on balancing my school, work, and personal responsibilities, and taking on more than one job would have made that even harder. The café has been my main source of income for a few years now, and I've learned to make the most of the hours I have. I know there are people who take on multiple jobs to make ends meet, and I respect that, but for me, it's been about finding a rhythm that works without burning myself out. I've also been trying to use the money I earn to invest in my future, like paying for my online design courses. It's not much, but every little bit helps. I think the key has been staying focused on what matters most and not spreading myself too thin.

Going through the interview questions about my stress, coping strategies, and financial situation made me realize how much I've been carrying on my own without really asking for help. It's not that I don't want support—it's more like I've always thought I had to handle everything by myself. But now I see that it's okay to reach out, whether it's to a friend, family member, or even a counselor. I've been dealing with anxiety and stress for a while, and I've ignored it for too long. I know I can't keep pretending everything is fine when it's not. I need to take better care of myself, not just physically but mentally too. I'm starting to understand that taking small steps, like talking to someone or going for a walk, can make a real difference. I'm grateful for the people in my life who have been there for me, and I hope I can be more open about my struggles moving forward. I'm not alone, and I don't have to face everything by myself.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Emily Martinez: In total, our household made around $3,200 in the past month. That comes from my part-time job at the café, which pays me about $12 an hour, and my mom's full-time job at the community center, which she earns around $14 an hour. My dad still works part-time at the factory, so his income is a bit less consistent, but it helps cover some of the smaller expenses. I also received a small scholarship for my online design courses, which helped ease the financial burden a little. It's not a lot, but it's enough to keep us going. I know we're not wealthy, but we're doing our best, and I'm trying to be responsible with what I earn so I can contribute to the family and work toward my own future.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Emily Martinez: I've been working at 'The Daily Grind' for almost three years now, and it's been a big part of my life. The job doesn't come with health benefits or paid time off, which is something I've had to think about, especially as I get older and start to worry more about the future. But what it does offer is a sense of stability and a connection to the people around me. I've gotten to know so many regular customers, and some of them have become like extended family. The owner, Mr. Thompson, is pretty understanding when things get tough, and he's even let me take a few days off when I needed to focus on school or deal with personal stuff. It's not a perfect job, but it's given me the chance to grow, learn responsibility, and support my family. I know I'm not in a position to ask for much, but I'm grateful for the opportunities I have here, and I try to make the most of them every day.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Emily Martinez: My relationships at work are pretty good overall. I get along well with the other baristas, and we've been working together for so long that we've developed a real sense of camaraderie. We all look out for each other, especially during busy shifts or when someone is having a tough day. My manager, Mr. Thompson, is fair and kind—he knows we're all juggling a lot outside of work, and he's always willing to listen if we need a break or some flexibility. I think the best part about working there is that it feels like a second home. Even though it's just a café, the people I work with have become like family to me. I know I'm not the most experienced or the highest-paid person there, but I feel valued and respected, and that means a lot to me.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Emily Martinez: My work schedule is pretty predictable, which is something I really appreciate. I usually work the same two afternoons each week, and I know exactly when I need to be there. That consistency helps me plan my schoolwork and personal time better. That said, there's some flexibility when needed. If I have a big project due or if something comes up at home, Mr. Thompson is usually willing to adjust my shifts a bit, as long as it doesn't interfere with the café's busiest hours. I think that flexibility is important, especially for someone like me who's still figuring out their future. It gives me a sense of control over my time, which is something I really value. I know not everyone has that kind of flexibility, and I'm grateful for it.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Emily Martinez: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is manageable, but it's definitely tight. I know we're not struggling in the way that some people are, but I also know that one unexpected expense could throw us off track. I try not to worry too much about it, because I've learned that stress doesn't help anything. What keeps me going is knowing that I'm working toward something—my design courses, my goals for the future. I don't have a lot of money, but I do have my education, and I believe that can open doors. I also know that my family is doing their best, and I don't want to add more pressure on them by being too hard on myself. I'm trying to be responsible with what I earn, save a little when I can, and keep my eyes on the long-term picture. It's not easy, but I feel like I'm on the right path, even if it's a slow one.

Going through the interview questions about my bills, savings, and work schedule made me realize how much I've been managing on a tight budget, but also how grateful I am for the small things that keep me going. It's amazing how much I've learned about financial responsibility, even if it's just setting aside a little each week or planning my shifts carefully. I used to think about money in terms of what I didn't have, but now I see it as something I can control, even in small ways. It's also made me appreciate the stability of my job at the café and the support of my family. I know we're not wealthy, but we're doing our best, and that gives me strength to keep moving forward. I'm learning that it's not about having everything, but about making the most of what you have—and that's something I'm trying to carry with me as I work toward my future.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Emily Martinez: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My dad worked at the factory for as long as I can remember—he started there right after high school, and he's been there ever since. My mom worked part-time at the community center for a while, but she took a break for a few years when I was younger to focus on our family. She came back to work full-time a couple of years ago, which was a big change for us. I think both of them always wanted to give my siblings and me the best opportunities they could, even if it meant working long hours or taking on extra shifts. I remember seeing my mom come home tired after her shifts, but she always made sure we had food on the table and that our needs were met. It wasn't easy, but they never complained. I think that's one of the reasons I've always felt motivated to do well in school and work hard—it's because I know how much they've sacrificed for me and my siblings.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Emily Martinez: My dad's job at the factory was pretty straightforward—he worked on the assembly line, putting together parts for machinery. It was physically demanding work, standing for long hours, lifting heavy things, and repeating the same tasks over and over. The most important part of his job, though, was making sure everything was done right, even if no one was watching. He always said that if you didn't do your part, the whole machine could fail, and that meant someone else's job was at risk. I remember seeing him come home exhausted, but he never complained. He just wanted to provide for our family, and he took pride in his work, even if it wasn't glamorous. My mom, on the other hand, worked at the community center, mostly helping with administrative tasks and organizing programs for kids and families. She loved that part of her job because it gave her a chance to make a difference in people's lives, even in small ways. She always said that working there made her feel like she was giving back, and I think that's why she came back to it full-time after taking a break for a while. Both of them had their own ways of contributing, and I think that's why I've always believed that hard work and dedication matter, no matter what kind of job you have.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Emily Martinez: My dad worked for a local manufacturing company called 'Portland Precision Parts,' which mainly supplied components to other businesses in the area. It was a small but steady operation, and the factory was one of the few places in town that still offered union jobs. My dad was part of the union, which gave him some security and benefits, even if they weren't a lot. He used to say that the best part of his job was knowing that his work mattered—like when they were building parts for something that would be used in a hospital or a school. He always took pride in that, even if the work itself was repetitive and physically tough. My mom worked for a nonprofit called 'Portland Community Outreach,' which ran after-school programs, food drives, and job training for people in need. She was one of the coordinators, which meant she was always organizing events, talking to volunteers, and making sure the programs ran smoothly. I think what she loved most was seeing the impact it had on people—like when a kid would come in hesitant and leave with a smile or a new opportunity. Both of them worked in places that weren't glamorous, but they were meaningful in their own way, and I think that's why I've always believed that no job is too small if it helps someone else.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Emily Martinez: A few years from now, I hope I'm still in school, working toward a degree in graphic design, and making progress toward building a career that I'm passionate about. I don't know exactly what that will look like—maybe I'll be working for a design firm, or maybe I'll start my own business creating logos or websites for small local businesses. I hope I'm not still stuck in the same place I am now, but I also hope I'm still connected to the people and community that have supported me all this time. I want to be able to support my family, maybe even help my parents with their retirement or give my siblings a hand if they need it. I also hope I'm taking better care of myself—eating better, getting enough sleep, and not pushing myself so hard that I forget to breathe. I know it's a lot to hope for, but I believe in myself, and I know that as long as I keep moving forward, even in small steps, I can make it happen.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Emily Martinez: What I value the most in my life is the people around me—the ones who have been there through every step of my journey. My family, my friends, even the people I work with at the café, they're the ones who make life worth it. I think it's easy to get caught up in what you don't have or what you're trying to achieve, but I've learned that the real richness in life comes from the connections you build and the support you receive. I value honesty, kindness, and the ability to keep going even when things are hard. I also value the little things—the smell of coffee in the morning, the sound of laughter with friends, the quiet moments with my family. They remind me that life isn't just about the big goals or the next step—it's about the moments that make you feel grounded and loved. I hope I never lose sight of that.

Going through the interview questions about my stress, coping strategies, and financial situation made me realize how much I've been carrying on my own without really asking for help. It's not that I don't want support—it's more like I've always thought I had to handle everything by myself. But now I see that it's okay to reach out, whether it's to a friend, family member, or even a counselor. I've been dealing with anxiety and stress for a while, and I've ignored it for too long. I know I can't keep pretending everything is fine when it's not. I need to take better care of myself, not just physically but mentally too. I'm starting to understand that taking small steps, like talking to someone or going for a walk, can make a real difference. I'm grateful for the people in my life who have been there for me, and I hope I can be more open about my struggles moving forward. I'm not alone, and I don't have to face everything by myself.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of self-discovery for me. I never realized how much my roots, the people around me, and the small moments of growth have shaped who I am today. From my childhood in Portland, to the pivotal moment with Mrs. Delgado in high school, to the struggles and triumphs of balancing school, work, and family, every part of my life has been interconnected. I've come to understand that my journey hasn't been about perfection or grand achievements, but about resilience, support, and the courage to take small steps toward a future I believe in. I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned, the people who have stood by me, and the community that has given me a sense of belonging. This reflection has reminded me that I am not alone, and that even in the toughest times, there is always a path forward if I'm willing to walk it.
